title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
The question was worth a maximum of 12 points. Points were allocated to each of the parts answered (a maximum of 3 points per part) and a further 3 points maximum was awarded for the use of examples in the answer as a whole.
Within each part answered, the 3 points were allocated as follows:

3 points - Good process-oriented understanding of how one factor links Rostow to contemporary economic and social change OR a more limited discussion or two or more factors.

2 points - Discussion of one factor that is incomplete in some way.

1 point - Identification of relevant factor without relevant/accurate discussion.

0 points - Attempt to answer, but response contains no relevant content.

Off task.

The responses for two or more parts could be interwoven, particularly parts (c) and (d), and readers were instructed to work with the students' responses in a way that would maximize the total points for the question as a whole.

A maximum of 3 points was available for the use of good examples. These points were allocated as follows:

3 points - Good appropriate example (almost always at the country level) for two or more parts of the question.

2 points - Less convincing; mostly country-level examples for two parts of the question OR a good example for only one part.

1 point - Countries used as examples not exactly appropriate.

0 points - All examples very general and inaccurate.

A single country could be used as an example for more than one part of this question if it was discussed in an appropriate way.

A good, process-oriented answer will explicitly recognize the usefulness of Rostow's treatment of a country's role in world economy in understanding contemporary ectonomic and social change. The Rostow model could be consid­ered a quite useful guide to change because it provides a means of assessing the magnitude and likely type of role a country may play, through its assertions that international trade is a key process for development and stage 5 countries are most developed and most influential. However, the Rostow model is less useful in helping our under­standing in those countries whose global role is more specialized (for example, as a member of a supranational group, as a labor exporter). Rostow is of little use in dependency theory-based accounts that link role in world economy and prospects for change to core-perihery position in the world economy.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
The question was worth a maximum of 12 points. Points were allocated to each of the parts answered (a maximum of 3 points per part) and a further 3 points maximum was awarded for the use of examples in the answer as a whole.
Within each part answered, the 3 points were allocated as follows:

3 points - Good process-oriented understanding of how one factor links Rostow to contemporary economic and social change OR a more limited discussion or two or more factors.

2 points - Discussion of one factor that is incomplete in some way.

1 point - Identification of relevant factor without relevant/accurate discussion.

0 points - Attempt to answer, but response contains no relevant content.

Off task.

The responses for two or more parts could be interwoven, particularly parts (c) and (d), and readers were instructed to work with the students' responses in a way that would maximize the total points for the question as a whole.

A maximum of 3 points was available for the use of good examples. These points were allocated as follows:

3 points - Good appropriate example (almost always at the country level) for two or more parts of the question.

2 points - Less convincing; mostly country-level examples for two parts of the question OR a good example for only one part.

1 point - Countries used as examples not exactly appropriate.

0 points - All examples very general and inaccurate.

A single country could be used as an example for more than one part of this question if it was discussed in an appropriate way.

A good, process-oriented answer will explicitly recognize that Rostow's treatment of colonial transport networks in understanding contemporary economic and social change is extremely limited. For example, the model does not consider the implications of external orientations to colonizers that are legacies of transport networks. Here, colonial transportation focused on ports with links to centers of resource exploitation and the most important function was to link the resource exploitation area (or its labor pool) to the world market. Furthermore, the model does not consider how colonial transport networks limit the internal growth of transportation systems and thus influence settlement patterns (urbanization). This can lead to regional disparities in growth, overurbanization, and a prolong­ing of primacy.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
The question was worth a maximum of 12 points. Points were allocated to each of the parts answered (a maximum of 3 points per part) and a further 3 points maximum was awarded for the use of examples in the answer as a whole.
Within each part answered, the 3 points were allocated as follows:

3 points - Good process-oriented understanding of how one factor links Rostow to contemporary economic and social change OR a more limited discussion or two or more factors.

2 points - Discussion of one factor that is incomplete in some way.

1 point - Identification of relevant factor without relevant/accurate discussion.

0 points - Attempt to answer, but response contains no relevant content.

Off task.

The responses for two or more parts could be interwoven, particularly parts (c) and (d), and readers were instructed to work with the students' responses in a way that would maximize the total points for the question as a whole.

A maximum of 3 points was available for the use of good examples. These points were allocated as follows:

3 points - Good appropriate example (almost always at the country level) for two or more parts of the question.

2 points - Less convincing; mostly country-level examples for two parts of the question OR a good example for only one part.

1 point - Countries used as examples not exactly appropriate.

0 points - All examples very general and inaccurate.

A single country could be used as an example for more than one part of this question if it was discussed in an appropriate way.

Most (but not all) good, process-oriented responses will explicitly
recognize that the Rostow model does not gener­ally consider cultural differences in accounting for patterns of economic and social change.

Examples of the impor­tance of cultural differences in affecting contemporary economic and social change are widespread, and include (but are not limited to):

Religion — Hindus (although more than a religion) may hinder development of middle class because of caste system preventing upward mobility.

Language — different languages may provide barriers to information flow and full participation in eco­nomic processes.

Political beliefs — governments may wish to isolate their population from westernization to exert greater control over their subjects and territory.

Profit motive — some populations may not move through the stages because of a lack of interest in cash profit.

Colonial legacy — departed colonial rulers left behind a social and economic system (neo-colonial) that concentrates the majority of wealth in the hands of a few and/or did not create a social infrastructure capable of allowing the population to engage in new forms of economic activity.

Gender — gender roles in cultures limit participation of entire population in economy thereby limiting growth potential.

Instability and violence/war — direct destruction of population, infrastructure, wasting local wealth and discouraging investment from outside.

Most (but not all) good, process-oriented responses will explicitly
recognize that the Rostow model does not gener­ally consider cultural differences in accounting for patterns of economic and social change.

Examples of the impor­tance of cultural differences in affecting contemporary economic and social change are widespread, and include (but are not limited to):

Religion — Hindus (although more than a religion) may hinder development of middle class because of caste system preventing upward mobility.

Language — different languages may provide barriers to information flow and full participation in eco­nomic processes.

Political beliefs — governments may wish to isolate their population from westernization to exert greater control over their subjects and territory.

Profit motive — some populations may not move through the stages because of a lack of interest in cash profit.

Colonial legacy — departed colonial rulers left behind a social and economic system (neo-colonial) that concentrates the majority of wealth in the hands of a few and/or did not create a social infrastructure capable of allowing the population to engage in new forms of economic activity.

Gender — gender roles in cultures limit participation of entire population in economy thereby limiting growth potential.

Instability and violence/war — direct destruction of population, infrastructure, wasting local wealth and discouraging investment from outside.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
The question was worth a maximum of 12 points. Points were allocated to each of the parts answered (a maximum of 3 points per part) and a further 3 points maximum was awarded for the use of examples in the answer as a whole.
Within each part answered, the 3 points were allocated as follows:

3 points - Good process-oriented understanding of how one factor links Rostow to contemporary economic and social change OR a more limited discussion or two or more factors.

2 points - Discussion of one factor that is incomplete in some way.

1 point - Identification of relevant factor without relevant/accurate discussion.

0 points - Attempt to answer, but response contains no relevant content.

Off task.

The responses for two or more parts could be interwoven, particularly parts (c) and (d), and readers were instructed to work with the students' responses in a way that would maximize the total points for the question as a whole.

A maximum of 3 points was available for the use of good examples. These points were allocated as follows:

3 points - Good appropriate example (almost always at the country level) for two or more parts of the question.

2 points - Less convincing; mostly country-level examples for two parts of the question OR a good example for only one part.

1 point - Countries used as examples not exactly appropriate.

0 points - All examples very general and inaccurate.

A single country could be used as an example for more than one part of this question if it was discussed in an appropriate way.

As above, most (but not all) good, process-oriented responses will explicitly recognize that the Rostow model does not generally consider local social and class structures in accounting for patterns of economic and social change.

Examples of the importance of these factors in affecting contemporary economic and social change include:

Class divisions — a small elite may control the vast majority of wealth and have no incentive to invest in new forms of economic activity.

Lack of emergence of middle class — in countries with no middle class it is hard to have skilled labor and business people emerge who will carry economy to later stages or limited national market for locally pro­duced products.

Gender — gender roles within a state may create regional variations in economic participation or result in population growth that retards economic development.

Ethnicity and violence — inter-group hostility may create situations where infrastructure is destroyed, population lost, or some groups prevented from economic participation thereby preventing the country from moving from one state to another.

Ethnicity and unity — a group may refuse to participate and may hinder the rest of the country's popula­tion from achieving the conditions necessary for advancement.
